metadata.title: Preferable phosphate removal by nano-La(III) hydroxides modified mesoporous rice husk biochars: Role of the host pore structure and point of zero charge

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Science of the Total Environment
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /sc i totenv
Preferable phosphate removal by nano-La(III) hydroxides modified mesoporous rice husk biochars: Role of the host pore structure and point of zero charge
Qian Tang a,1, Chenghao Shi a,1, Wenmin Shi b, Xueling Huang a, Yuanyao Ye a,c, Wei Jiang a,⁎, Jianxiong Kang a, Dongqi Liu a, Yongzheng Ren a, Daosheng Li a
a School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, No. 1037 Luoyu Road, Wuhan 430074, PR China b China Construction Third Bureau Green Industry Investment Co. Ltd, Wuhan, Hubei 430056, PR China c Centre for Technology in Water and Wastewater, School of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of Technology Sydney, Sydney, NSW 2007, Australia
H I G H L I G H T S G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
• Rice husk biochars can serve as preferable host material for La(OH)3 nanoparticles. • La-modified rice husk biochars exhibited superior La utilization efficiency. • Phosphate can be captured over a wide pH rang of 3–10 with negligible La leaching. • Coexisting Ca2+ inhibited the phosphate adsorption, while Mg2+
enhanced the process.
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: jiangwei0707@hust.edu.cn (W. Jiang) 1 These two authors contributed equally to this paper.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2019.01.159 0048-9697/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 12 October 2018 Received in revised form 27 December 2018 Accepted 13 January 2019 Available online 15 January 2019
Editor: Baoliang Chen
Immobilizing La(OH)3 nanoparticles (NPs) to porous hosts has been widely applied to inhibiting their inherent aggregation as well as the subsequent low utilization efficiency of La. In this study, a series of rice husk biochars (RHBCs) with high mesoporous rates were prepared and the effects of host pore structure and point of zero charge (pHpzc) on phosphate adsorption by La-modified RHBCswas particularly focused. Characterization results confirmed that La(OH)3 NPs were both confined in the pore channel and external surface of RHBCs. Adsorption kinetics and isotherms showed that La-modifiedRHBCswith highermesoporous rates of the host showed a faster adsorption rate and La-modified RHBCs exhibited superior La utilization efficiency than many reported Laincorporated adsorbents. Phosphate could be effectively captured over a wide pH of 3–10 due to the high pHpzc of La-modified RHBCs. Moreover, the La-modified RHBCs showed satisfactory affinity towards phosphate in the presence of coexisting anions and the phosphate adsorption by La-RHBC9 was enhanced in the presence of Ca2+, while it was inhibited in the presence of Mg2+. The mesoporous structure of RHBCs strengthened the stability of La-modified RHBCs and weakened the inhibition of coexisting humic substances on phosphate adsorption through the “shielding effect”.

Keywords: Phosphate removal Rice husk biochar Lanthanum hydroxide Mesoporous structure
.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Excessive emission of phosphate into the aqueous environment has been confirmed to lead to eutrophication by abnormally accelerating
the growth of algae and reducing the dissolved oxygen concentrations, which further causedwater quality deterioration and aquatic ecosystem collapse (Conley et al., 2009). In recent decades, various materials, such as metal hydroxides (Chitrakar et al., 2006; Xie et al., 2014), layered double hydroxides (Cai et al., 2012; Zhang et al., 2013), zeolites (Chen et al., 2006) and redmud (Ye et al., 2015), have been used for phosphate adsorption and removal. In particular, lanthanum (La) has attracted extensive attention in phosphate sequestration because of its high adsorption capacity, environmentally-friendly properties and its specific affinity towards phosphate (Dong et al., 2017; He et al., 2017; Koilraj and Sasaki, 2017). Nevertheless, pure lanthanum hydroxides have rarely been applied to phosphate removal because bulk lanthanum nanoparticles turned to aggregating in water, which led to incomplete accessibility of La to coordinate with phosphate and resulted in low La utilization efficiency (Koilraj and Sasaki, 2017; Yang et al., 2011). To overcome this problem, various La-incorporated adsorbents that functioned by immobilizing La onto the surface or pore channels of porous materials, such as zeolites (He et al., 2017), activated carbon fiber (Liu et al., 2013), macroporous ordered silica foams (Yang et al., 2012) and polymeric resins (Zhang et al., 2016), have been developed for phosphate removal. The adsorption properties of different La-incorporated adsorbents varied dramatically with the differences in host materials. Thus, it is of great significance to develop superior host material for La to enhance both the phosphate adsorption properties and La utilization efficiency.
Biochar, which can be produced from various waste biomass materials in an oxygen-limited environment, has recently drawn increasing attention as an alternative low-cost, environmentally friendly and effective adsorbent for environmental pollutants (Sizmur et al., 2017; Tan et al., 2015). When compared to macroporous ordered silica foams (Yang et al., 2012; Yang et al., 2011) and cross-linked polystyrene (Zhang et al., 2016), porous biochar could serve as a preferable hostmaterial for La because of their considerable porosity, resistance to degradation, and their ability to minimize recontamination in the fabrication process. In previous studies, lanthanum loaded biochar (Wang et al., 2016), La-porous carbon composites (Koilraj and Sasaki, 2017), nano-La(III) (hydr)oxides modified wheat straw (Qiu et al., 2017) and iron-modified biochars (Yang et al., 2018), have been developed and used for phosphate removal. However, most studies conducted to date focused on the effects of ordinary parameters (e.g., metal loadings, solution pH and coexisting anions), while the effects of textural properties of the host materials (e.g., surface area and pore size distribution) have rarely been studied. According to previous studies, the host pore structure would have a significant impact on the size and shape of the immobilized NPs and further influence their adsorption performance (Wang et al., 2011; Yang et al., 2012; Yang et al., 2011; Zhang et al., 2017). Previous studies have also demonstrated that the mesopore structure of the host materials could significantly alleviate pore blockage during phosphate adsorption (Yang et al., 2012; Yang et al., 2011). Moreover, Prashanth Suresh Kumar et al. showed that phosphate adsorption at lower phosphate concentrations by iron oxide coated granular activated carbons was mainly contributed by mesopores areas (porous area of N3 nm of the adsorbents) (Suresh Kumar et al., 2017). However, the support material of La-incorporated carbon composites (e.g., lanthanum-doped activated carbon fiber, lanthanum loaded biochar and La-porous carbon composites) weremainly rich inmicropores (Koilraj and Sasaki, 2017; Liu et al., 2013;Wang et al., 2016). Hence,we pose thehypothesis that La-incorporated carbon composite with a mesoporous structure of the host material may have a superior phosphate removal performance.
Rice husk (RH) is a major agricultural by-product of rice milling industry and one of the most commonly available lignocellulosic materials with a high ash content and high silicon levels (Lin et al., 2013). In previous studies, RHwas used as a precursor for fabrication of porous silica and carbon materials (Shen et al., 2014). Moreover, many studies have shown that the textural properties of biochars could be improved
by physical and chemical activation (Guo and Rockstraw, 2007; Le Van and Luong Thi, 2014; Sizmur et al., 2017). In this study, we prepared a series of RH biocharswith a highmesoporous rate using a CO2 activation method followed by NaOH post-treatment to achieve silicon removal based on previous studies (Li and Zhu, 2014). The unique textural properties of RHBCs may serve as a satisfactory host material for generation of superior La accommodation properties and subsequently preferable phosphate removal performance. Thus, the objective of the present study was to fabricate a series of mesoporous rice husk biochars and study the effects of the host pore structure on La immobilization and the corresponding phosphate adsorption performance of La-modified RHBCs. The general physicochemical properties of RHBCs and Lamodified RHBCs were extensively characterized and their phosphate adsorption performance (adsorption kinetics and isotherm, effect of solution pH) were examined. The effects of coexisting substances such as common competitive anions, dissolved humic acid and the presence of Ca2+ andMg2+ on phosphate adsorption were also investigated. Moreover, themain adsorptionmechanism for preferable phosphate adsorption by La-modified RHBCs was also discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: The rice husks were collected from Honghu (N29.48°, E113.27°), Hubei Province, China. All chemicals used in this study, including La (NO3)3·nH2O (molecular weight 324.92), Ca(NO3)2·4H2O, Mg(NO3) 2·6H2O andKH2PO4,were analytical grade andusedwithout further purification. All reagents were purchased from Sinopharm Chemicals Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China) and all chemical solutions were prepared with ultrapure water.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Preparation of rice husk biochars
sections.text:
After the pyrolysis of RHs at 800 °C for 1 h in a N2 atmosphere and then a full exposure to a CO2 atmosphere for 2 h, RHBCs were formed (Li and Zhu, 2014). The RHBCs was then boiled in 2 M NaOH solution (3h for RHBC3 and 9 h for RHBC9), the biocharswerewashedwith ultrapurewater until the pHof thefiltratewas neutral. Next, the RHBCswere dried in an oven at 105 °C overnight. Finally, thematerials were ground into fine powder with a mortar. The resultant biochar samples were used as host materials for the preparation of La-modified RHBCs.
2.2.2. Preparation of La-modified rice husk biochars In this study, La-modified adsorbents were prepared by facile coprecipitation method. Briefly, certain amounts of hydrated lanthanum nitrate and biochars in a mass ratio (La/biochars) of 0.2 were added to 100 mL ultrapure water and subjected to magnetic stirring for 4 h. Next, 28% ammonia solution was slowly dropped into the samples to produce participates and increase the pH to 11.5. The La-modified RHBCswere centrifuged after 24 h and repeatedly rinsedwith ultrapure water to reduce the pH to around 7.0. Finally, the adsorbents were dried at 105 °C for 24 h. The scheme of the preparation procedure of RHBCs and La-modified RHBCs is given in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 2.3. Batch adsorption experiments
sections.text:
Phosphate stock solution containing 100 mg P/L was prepared by dissolving the desired amounts of anhydrous KH2PO4 in ultrapure water, after which the stock solution was diluted to prepare phosphate solution of various concentrations. The phosphate adsorption kinetics on La-modified RHBCs were subsequently evaluated by adding 0.0120 g La-modified RHBCs to 50 mL centrifuge tubes containing 40 mL phosphate solution, after which the tubes were shaken in a thermostatic oscillator (Changzhou Zhiborui InstrumentManufacturing Co.,
Ltd.) for 12 h at 25 °C. Supernatant liquid was taken out at a fixed time, afterwhich the solutionwasfiltered using afiltermembranewith a 0.45 μmpore size and the equilibrium concentration of phosphatewas determined bymonitoring the absorbance at 700 nmon anUV-1780 spectrophotometer using the ascorbic acid method (Liu et al., 2013; Shi et al., 2019) (Shimadzu Corporation, Japan). The phosphate adsorption isotherm on La-modified RHBCs was studied by adding 0.0120 g Lamodified RHBCs to 40 mL phosphate solution of different concentrations (5–100 mg P/L) in centrifuge tubes. Next, the tubes were then shaken in a thermostatic oscillator for 24 h at 25 °C. The effects of solution pH ranging from 2.0 to 12.0 on phosphate adsorption were measured at 25 °C, the pH value was adjusted by 0.1 M HNO3 or NaOH. Additionally, coexisting substances such as Na2SO4, NaHCO3, NaF, humic acid, Ca(NO3)2 and Mg(NO3)2 were introduced to examine their effects on phosphate adsorption.

sections.heading: 2.4. Analysis methods
sections.text: The resultant La loadings on La-modified RHBCswere determined by digesting the composite with aqua regia and then analyzing them by ICP-OES (Perkin-Elmer Optima 8300, USA). The contents of C, H, O and N of RHBCs and La-modified RHBCs were characterized using an elemental analyzer (Elementar 28 Vario MICRO cube, Germany). The content of Si was analyzed by X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (AxiosmAx, PANalytical, Netherlands). The textural properties of RHBCs and Lamodified biochars were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption at 77 K on an ASAP 2020 V4.00 (Micromeritics Instrument Corporation, UK). The micropores and mesopores of RHBCs were characterized using the HK (Horvath-Kawazoe) and BJH (Barrett-Joyner-Halenda) model, respectively. The point of zero charge (pHpzc) was measured by pH drift method. Surface morphologies of RHBCs and La-modified biochars were observed with a scanning electron microscopy (SEM; Sigma 300, Zeiss, Germany). The microscopic features of the Lamodified RHBCs were observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM; Tecnai G2 20, FEI, Horan). X-ray photoelectron spectra of Lamodified RHBCs and the composite after phosphate adsorption were collected using amonochromated Al KαX-ray source at 150W (Escalab 250Xi, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). The crystallographic phases of RHBCs and La-modified RHBCswere investigated using anX-ray diffractometer with Cu/Kα radiation (40 kV, 30 mA) (XRD-7000, Shimadzu, Japan) at a 6°/min scanning speed and 0.014° step size. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR) of La-modified RHBCs before and after phosphate adsorption were determined by spectroscopy (FTIR; VERTEX 70, Bruker, Germany).

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
3.1. Characterization of RHBCs and La-modified RHBCs
The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the resultant RHBCs fabricated under different activation conditions are illustrated in Fig. 2. All three isotherms exhibited a mixture of Type I and IV uptake as per the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) (Lin et al., 2013). The Type I uptake at lower relative pressures is characteristic of
microporous materials, while the H3 hysteresis loop confirmed the occurrence of well-connected mesostructured phases after posttreatmentwithNaOH (Le Van and Luong Thi, 2014; Lin et al., 2013). Notably, the distinct changes in the shape and N2 adsorption amount demonstrated that post-treatment with NaOH and boiling time had a significant impact on the pore development of RHBCs. The corresponding textural properties of the RHBCs are summarized in Table 1. Compared to RHBC, the BET surface area and pore volume of RHBC3 increased significantly after post-treatment with NaOH, while that of RHBC9 decreased slightly compared to RHBC3. These observations can be attributed to the release of silicon components during NaOH posttreatment as depicted in Eq. (1) (Le Van and Luong Thi, 2014; Shen et al., 2014).
nSiO2 þ 2NaOH→Na2O nSiO2 þH2O ð1Þ
This assumption was further supported by the elemental composition of RHBCs. As shown in Table S1, the carbon content sharply increased in RHBC3 and RHBC9, while the silicon contents sharply decreased after NaOH post-treatment. The dissolution of SiO2 component in RHBC resulted in the formation of additional microspores and mesopores in RHBC3 (Shen et al., 2014; Yalçin and Sevinç, 2001). However, the longer boiling time of RHBC9 enabled sufficient reaction according to Eq. (1) and resulted in damage to the micropores and mesopores that had already formed (Guo et al., 2002). As shown in Table 1, the resultant mesoporous rate of RHBC, RHBC3 and RHBC9 was determined to be 43.8%, 47.1% and 56.2%, respectively. The pore size distributions of RHBCs (see Fig. S1) further confirmed the existence of a high fraction of mesopores. The relatively high BET surface areas
and well-developed mesoporous structures of RHBCs was probably superior for La immobilization and subsequent phosphate removal.
After immobilization of La, the specific surface area of La-modified RHBCs decreased obviously, which might be attributed to poreblockage caused by the precipitation process (Koilraj and Sasaki, 2017; Zhang et al., 2016). According to a previous study, the ionic radius and hydrated radius of La3+ was 0.1032 nm and 0.452 nm, respectively (Tansel et al., 2006). In contrast, the average pore width of RHBC, RHBC3 and RHBC9 was calculated to be 4.0 nm, 5.8 nm and 5.9 nm, respectively (Table 1), which indicated the La3+ could diffuse into the mesopores and macropores of RHBCs. Accordingly, the La(OH)3 NPs could be immobilized to both the external surface and thepore channels of the RHBCs. Moreover, the La loadings in La-RHBC, La-RHBC3 and LaRHBC9 as determined by ICP-OES showed slight increases and the resultant La contents were 11.96%, 12.60% and 12.85%, respectively. Thus, the higher mesoporous rate of the host may result in higher La loading of the La-modified RHBCs.
Fig. 3 presents the XRD patterns of RHBCs and La-modified RHBCs. Obviously, characteristic peaks of SiC (JCPDS 49-1623) were observed in the three RHBCs and NaOH post-treatment enhanced the intensity
Fig. 3.X-ray diffraction patterns of RHBCs (a) and La-modified RHBCs (b); transmission electron RHBC9, respectively.
of SiC peaks. Interestingly, the La(OH)3 NPs were poorly crystallized in La-RHBC and appeared as an amorphous structure; however, a highly crystalline structure was observed in La-RHBC3 and La-RHBC9, which was due to the reflections from the hexagonal phase of La(OH)3 (JCPDS 36-1481). The corresponding TEM images of La-modified RHBCs shown in Fig. 3 confirmed that La(OH)3 NPs had a rod-like morphology with a length of 80–230 nm and a diameter of 8–23 nm in RHBC3 and RHBC9, which was in line with other observations in the literature (He et al., 2015). The surface morphologies of RHBCs were further examined and are shown in Fig. S2. Compared to RHBC, the surface of RHBC3 and RHBC9 were relatively coarse at higher magnifications, which was more favorable for La immobilization. The unique characteristic diffraction peak of RHBC, RHBC3, and RHBC9 suggested that the NaOH post-treatment and the host pore structure had a significant effect on the crystallization of immobilized La(OH)3 NPs.
In our recent study, we demonstrated that increased pHpzc of the adsorbent would significantly enhance tolerance of the adsorbent towards variations in pH (Shi et al., 2019). Thus, the pHpzc of RHBCs and Lamodified RHBCs was further determined and the results are listed in Table 1. The pHpzc values of La-modified RHBCs were higher than many La-based adsorbents reported in previous studies (Liu et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2016; Zhang et al., 2012). The high pHpzc implied that the La-modified RHBCs would be positively charged over a wide pH range (pH b pHpzc) and could effectively sequestrate phosphate owing to the strong electrostatic attraction. A detailed discussion of the role of pHpzc can be found in Section 3.3.

sections.heading: 3.2. Adsorption kinetics and isotherm
sections.text:
The phosphate adsorption kinetics of La-modified RHBCs are depicted in Fig. 4. The La-modified RHBCs with higher mesoporous rate of the host exhibited a superior adsorption capacity. Compared to the pseudo first-ordermodel, the pseudo second-ordermodel better represented all of the adsorption kinetics of La-modified RHBCs (see Table 2 for details), which confirmed that the phosphate adsorption processes by La-modified RHBCs were controlled by
microscope images of La-modified RHBCs: (c), (d) and (e) for La-RHBC, La-RHBC3, and La-
chemical interaction (He et al., 2017; Koilraj and Sasaki, 2017). The equilibrium adsorption capacities of La-RHBC, La-RHBC3 and LaRHBC9 obtained from the pseudo second-order model were 23.82 mg P/g, 24.10 mg P/g and 25.04 mg P/g, respectively, which were close to the experimental data. Moreover, the increasing adsorption rate constant (k2) of La-RHBC, La-RHBC3 and La-RHBC9 (0.0023 b 0.0036 b 0.0052 g/(mg·min)) indicated the adsorption process was much faster for La-modified RHBCs with a higher mesoporous rate of the host.
To further quantitatively describe the adsorption rate of phosphate by La-modified RHBCs, the intra-particle diffusionmodelwas employed to represent the kinetic data. As shown in Fig. 4b, the multi-stage linear fit of the Qt vs t0.5 indicating the adsorption processes of phosphate adsorption on La-modified RHBCs was controlled by intra-particle diffusion, which was similar to the results of previous studies (He et al., 2016; Huang et al., 2014; Shi et al., 2019). The adsorption process could be roughly divided into three stages, a fast stage followed by a relatively slow stage and then an extremely slow equilibrium stage. Interestingly, the diffusion rate constant kd1 followed the order La-RHBC3
N La-RHBC9 N La-RHBC, while the diffusion rate constant kd2 followed the order La-RHBC9 N La-RHBC3 N La-RHBC (see Table 2 for details). These phenomena could be well interpreted by the following aspects. The first adsorption stage was suggested to be driven by differences in concentration and electrostatic attraction through film diffusion (He et al., 2017; Shi et al., 2019). The La(OH)3 NPs were both confined in the external surface and pore channels of RHBCs as mentioned in Section 3.1, and the pore structure of the host may impact the distribution of La(OH)3 NPs. The resultant average pore width of RHBCs followed the order La-RHBC3 N La-RHBC9 N La-RHBC (Table 1), indicating that a larger pore size results in a faster diffusion rate of RHBC3 in thefirst stage. Following the instantaneous occupation ofmost available surface sites, phosphate entered the inner portion of the La-modified RHBCs, and the diffusion resistance increased, thereby causing the intra-particle diffusion rate (kd2 b kd1) to decrease (He et al., 2016; Shi et al., 2019). Moreover, the order of the diffusion rate constant kd2 indicated that intra-particle diffusion of La(OH)3 NPs instead of the RHBCs host seems to be the rate-controlling step (He et al., 2016; Zhang et al., 2017).
In addition, the phosphate adsorption isotherms of La-modified RHBCs were assessed and depicted in Fig. 4c. A similar phenomenon was observed, i.e., the adsorption capacity of La-modified RHBCs increased as the mesoporous rate of the host increased. As seen in Table S2, the higher correlation coefficients indicated that the experimental data can be better described by the Langmuir model (R2 N 0.90) than the Freundlich model (R2 b 0.90), which indicated that the adsorption of phosphate on La-modified RHBCs was caused via amonolayer homogeneous adsorption process (Koilraj and Sasaki, 2017;Wang et al., 2016). The maximum adsorption capacity of La-RHBC, La-RHBC3 and La-RHBC9was 41.22mg P/g, 43.26mgP/g and 45.62mgP/g, respectively. Notably, phosphate adsorption onto the host RHBCs was negligible (data not shown), indicating that the immobilized La(OH)3 NPs are the only active sites of La-modified RHBCs. This was further confirmed by the EDS elemental mappings exhibited in Fig. S3, which indicated that the distribution of the adsorbed P overlapped well with the confined La element.
To further evaluate the adsorption performance of La-modified RHBCs, we compared them with some other La-incorporated adsorbents used for phosphate removal described in the literature. Generally, most studies conducted to date have only gauged the performance of the adsorbents in terms of the resultant adsorption capacity, and these were mainly expressed in terms of the mass of total adsorbents, while only a few of investigations have focused on the La utilization efficiency, which can be expressed in terms of La (i.e., the P/La molar ratio). Moreover, the adsorption conditions (e.g., pH, temperature, dosage, and initial P concentration range) are generally ignored which would pose a significant impact on the adsorption capacity. Hence, we extensively evaluated the adsorption performance of La-modified RHBCs with other La-incorporated adsorbents based on the above issues (Dong et al., 2017; Haghseresht et al., 2009; He et al., 2017; Huang et al., 2014; Shin et al., 2005; Xie et al., 2014; Yang et al., 2011; Zhang et al., 2012; Zhang et al., 2016) (see Table 3 for details). The results indicated that La-modified RHBCs showed passable adsorption capacities in phosphate removal. However, the resultant P/La molar ratios of La-modified RHBCs were obviously higher than those of many previously reported adsorbents, which indicated outstanding utilization efficiencies of La immobilized to RHBCs. For example, the P/La molar ratio in La100SBA15 and ACF-LaOH was 0.88 and 1.10, respectively, which was significantly lower than that of La-modified RHBCs (Yang et al., 2011; Zhang et al., 2012). The higher La utilization efficiencies of La-modified RHBCs could be ascribed to differences in the Lanthanum species, La content and the special pore structure of the host. Specifically, previous studies showed that lanthanum hydroxides may provide more adsorption sites (i.e., surface hydroxyl groups) than lanthanum oxides (Wu et al., 2017; Zhang et al., 2012). Additionally, the La content in LaRHBC, La-RHBC3 and La-RHBC9 was 11.96 wt%, 12.60 wt% and 12.85 wt%, respectively, which was relatively lower than that of other La-incorporated adsorbents (e.g., La100SBA-15, 23.3 wt%). Moreover,
the high surface area and the mesoporous structure of the RHBCs guaranteed the relatively homogeneous distribution of La(OH)3 NPs (Fig. S3), which together enhanced the accessibility of La(OH)3 active sites to coordinate with phosphate.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of pH, toxicity analysis and mechanism study
sections.text:
The results of the effect of pH on phosphate adsorption on the three La-modifiedRHBCs are depicted in Fig. 5a. Clearly, the three La-modified RHBCs showed the same trends with the variations in pH, which is consistent with many previously reported La-incorporated composites (He et al., 2015; Liao et al., 2018; Wu et al., 2017). It should be noted that phosphate adsorption on La-modified RHBCs fluctuated slightly within the pH range of 3–10, indicating La-modified RHBCs exhibited superior tolerance towards variations in pH because effective phosphate sequestration could only be achieved within a narrow pH range at acidic pH levels by many of the reported La-incorporated adsorbents.
The release of metal ions during phosphate adsorption is a major concern that may induce potential environmental risk. However, previous studies showed that La-incorporated adsorbents containing high La loadings such as ACF-LaOH and ACF-LaFe, exhibited significant amounts of La leachingduringphosphate adsorption (Liu et al., 2013; Zhang et al., 2012). To evaluate the stability and the toxicity of La-modified RHBCs, the La leaching contents at varying pH were determined by ICP-OES. As shown in Fig. 5b, when pH= 2, 99.03 wt%, 73.09 wt% and 44.31 wt % (calculated by the mass balance) of the total La was leached from La-RHBC, La-RHBC3 and La-RHBC9, respectively. Notably, only 1.44 wt %, 0.98 wt% and 0.82 wt% of the total La for La-RHBC, La-RHBC3 and La-RHBC9, respectively, was leached at pH 3, while negligible La leaching was observed as the pH exceeded 3.0. Thus, as discussed in our previous study (Shi et al., 2019), it is environmentally benign to use La-modified RHBCs for effective phosphate removal without causing substantial adverse effects on aquatic ecosystems at an optimal dosage (e.g., 0.3 g/L) within the pH range of 3–10. The superior stability of La-modified RHBCs was mainly attributed to the special mesoporous structure of the RHBCs, which improved the stability of encapsulated lanthanum hydroxide through a “shielding effect”. Specifically, the majority of La active sites were anchored on the external surface of activated carbon materials because of their micropore structure, whereas La(OH)3 NPswere both immobilized in the pore channels and to the external surface of the RHBCs as discussed in Section 3.1. In sum, the Lamodified RHBCs exhibited superior tolerance towards pH variations and satisfactory stability during phosphate removal.
Furthermore, the effect of pH on phosphate adsorption on Lamodified biochars could be interpretedwell upon analysis of phosphate species distribution at different pH values and the role of pHpzc of the adsorbents (Shi et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2012). Overall, the sharp decrease in adsorption capacity of La-modified biochars at pH = 2 (Fig. 5a) was mainly attributed to the dissolution of La active sites as
ted adsorbents for phosphate removal.
discussed above (Fig. 5b). As shown in Fig. S3, H2PO4− and HPO42− were the dominant species in the pH range of 3–11 (Fig. S2). Generally, H2PO4− could bemore easily adsorbed than HPO42− due to the lower adsorption free energy (Li et al., 2016). Moreover, the protonation and deprotonation of the surface of the adsorbents also played a key role. When the pH b pHpzc, the negative H2PO4− and HPO42− could be effectively captured to the protonated surface of the La-modified RHBCs through strong electrostatic attraction (Liu et al., 2013; Shi et al., 2019). In contrast, when pH N pHpzc, the negatively charged adsorbent would significantly inhibit phosphate adsorption through electrostatic repulsion (Liu et al., 2013; Zhang et al., 2012). Moreover, the high concentration of hydroxyl ions would strongly compete for the active site (i.e., surface hydroxyl groups) with phosphate under strong alkaline conditions. Thus, the superior performance of La-modified RHBCs towards pH variation was mainly ascribed to the high pHpzc of Lamodified RHBCs, which enhanced phosphate adsorption through strong electrostatic attraction over a wide pH range of 3–10.
The adsorption mechanism of phosphate on La-incorporated adsorbentswas believed to form an inner-sphere complex on La (hydr)oxides via a ligand exchange mechanism between phosphate and surfacecoordinated water molecules or hydroxyl ions (Shi et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2016). To further probe the adsorption mechanism of Lamodified RHBCs, the equilibrium pH after phosphate adsorption was measured and depicted in Fig. 5c. Notably, the equilibrium pH after phosphate adsorption was higher than the initial pH (red circle in Fig. 5c), illustrating an increase in hydroxyl ions in solution after phosphate adsorption. This phenomenonmight be interpreted as the release of hydroxyl ions from adsorbents through ligand exchange (Li et al., 2016; Shi et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2012). The ligand exchange process could be described by the following equations:
≡ La‐OHþH2PO4−→ ≡ La‐H2PO4 þ OH− 2:12bpHb7:21ð Þ ð2Þ
2 ≡ La‐OHþHPO42−→ ≡ Lað Þ2‐HPO4 þ 2OH− 7:21bpHb12:31ð Þ ð3Þ
At higher pH, the ligand exchange process was inhibited by the high concentration of hydroxyl ions in the solution, resulting in an insignificant change of ΔpH. The ligand exchange mechanism was further supported by the high resolution O 1s spectrum for La-RHBC9 (Fig. 5d). Clearly, the relative area ratio for M\\O increased while the relative area ratio for M\\OH decreased after phosphate, suggesting that the replacement of hydroxyl groups with phosphate occurred via ligand exchange (He et al., 2016; He et al., 2017; Yu and Paul Chen, 2015).
Complexation is another important mechanism in phosphate adsorption that can be confirmed by FTIR and XPS studies (Liao et al., 2018). As shown in Fig. S5, the typical peaks at 616 cm−1 and 545 cm−1 after phosphate adsorption were assigned to the bending vibration of O\\P\\O, suggesting the formation of an inner-sphere complex during adsorption (Liu et al., 2013; Shi et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2012). In addition, a peak of P 2p with a binding energy centered at 133.5 eV was clearly observed in La-RHBC9-P (Fig. S6a). The apparent shifts of ~0.5 eV to a lower energy level (standard P 2p spectrum of KH2PO4 centered at ~134.0 eV) indicated the formation of an innersphere complex between phosphate and La-RHBC9 (He et al., 2017; Qiu et al., 2017). The binding energies of La 3d3/2 and La 3d5/2 shifted slightly to higher values (Fig. S6b), which was attributed to the formation of a La\\O\\P inner-sphere complex (Qiu et al., 2017; Shi et al., 2019).
Precipitation was also estimated to be involved in the removal of phosphate in previous studies because of the low solubility product constant (Ksp) of LaPO4 (3.7 × 10−23). This was demonstrated well by the XRD patterns of La-modified RHBCs after phosphate adsorption as shown in Fig. S7. Clearly, typical characteristic peaks of LaPO4 (JCPDS 04-0635) were observed in all three composites, confirming the existence of precipitation process through the formation of LaPO4 (Liao et al., 2018; Wang et al., 2016). Moreover, the emerging needle-like
randomness of crystals shown in Fig. S8 were mainly attributed to the nucleation of La(OH)3 NPs and nanorods to form LaPO4 polycrystalline (Wang et al., 2016).
Taken together, these observations indicated that the phosphate adsorption mechanism for La-modified RHBCs mainly involved electrostatic interaction, ligand exchange, inner-sphere complexation and precipitation. The multiple adsorption mechanisms of La-modified RHBCs are shown in Fig. S9.

sections.heading: 3.4. Effects of coexisting substances on phosphate adsorption
3.4.1. Coexisting anions
sections.text:
Considering the complex chemistry of eutrophic water, we further evaluated the selectivity of La-modified RHBCs for phosphate. In this study, we selected several representative coexisting anions which might exert a significant negative influence on adsorption process based on previous studies. As shown in Fig. 6, the effects of SO42−, HCO3– and F− at different coexisting levels on phosphate removal by La-modified RHBCs were experimentally quantified. Clearly, SO42− exhibited a negligible impact on phosphate adsorption on La-modified RHBCs even at a high coexisting levels of 500mg/L (mass concentration ratio of SO42−/PO43− = 50) (Fig. 6a). Generally, SO42− is believed to inhibit the adsorption process via the formation of out-sphere complexes while phosphate could form stable inner-sphere complexes with the immobilized La(OH)3 NPs (Li et al., 2016; Liu et al., 2013). In the presence of high coexisting levels of HCO3– (mass concentration ratio of HCO3−/PO43−=50), La-modified RHBCs still showed preferable selectivity towards phosphate, only 11.4%, 11.6% and 12.6% capacity loss were observed for La-RHBC, La-RHBC3 and La-RHBC9, respectively (Fig. 6b). It is known that La2(CO3)3 (Ksp = 3.98 × 10−34) possesses a lower Ksp value than that of LaPO4 (Ksp = 3.7 × 10−23), which means that the immobilized La(OH)3 NPs may have superior affinity for the HCO3– than PO43−(He et al., 2016; Koilraj and Sasaki, 2017). Moreover, the hydrolysis of HCO3– (Kh = 2.25 × 10−7) would enhance the competitive adsorption between phosphate and hydroxyl ion (He et al., 2017; Koilraj and Sasaki, 2017; Shi et al., 2019).
In our previous study, coexisting F− at a mass concentration ratio of F−/PO43− = 25 exhibited dramatic inhibition on the phosphate

Obviously, similar effect on phosphate adsorption was observed, the adsorption capacity loss of La-RHBC, La-RHBC3 and La-RHBC9 was 12.5%, 30.3% and 40.3%, respectively. This is reasonable because of its similarity in chemical properties to HCO3−, i.e., to form inner-sphere complex with La(OH)3 and the buffering effects of increasing the concentration of hydroxyl ion (Shi et al., 2019). This outcome suggested that La-modified RHBCs may serve as an effective multifunctional adsorbent for the removal of phosphate along with fluorion.

sections.heading: 3.4.2. Humic acid
sections.text: Previous studies revealed that the adsorption of phosphate by Laincorporatedmaterials could be inhibited in the presence of humic substances (Koilraj and Sasaki, 2017; Zhang et al., 2016). Therefore, the effects of humic acid (HA) on phosphate adsorption by La-modified RHBCs were examined and the results were depicted in Fig. 6d. The phosphate adsorption capacity declined dramatically in the presence of 10 mg/L HA, whereas a further increase in the HA concentration had a negligible impact on phosphate adsorption. Because of the mesoporous structure of RHBCs, the La(OH)3 active sites were both confined in the pore channels and the external surface of the host as discussed in Section 3.1. According to previous study, the average molecular size of HAwas 1.2–4 nm (B. Lin et al., 2017). Thus, the coexisting HAwas difficult to diffuse into the internal region of La-modified RHBCs because of the size exclusion effects (B. Lin et al., 2017). This observation indicated that the host pore structure of RHBCs could attenuate the negative effects of coexisting substance with large molar size through a “shielding effect”.

sections.heading: 3.4.3. Coexisting cations
sections.text:
According to previous studies, the phosphate adsorption capacity of La-PC composite in seawater was twice that in fresh water and coexisting cations were believed to enhance the precipitation of phosphate on the surface of La in the La-PC composite (Koilraj and Sasaki, 2017). However, the individual effects of coexisting Ca2+ and Mg2+ was clearly not sufficient. Thus, the phosphate adsorption by La-

RHBC9 in the presence of Ca2+ and Mg2+ at pH 4 and pH 7 was studied and the results were shown in Fig. 6e. Interestingly, phosphate adsorptionwas enhanced in the presence of Ca2+, while it was inhibited in the presence of Mg2+. Moreover, when the solution pH increased from 4 to 7, the enhancement of Ca2+ and the inhibition of Mg2+ on phosphate adsorption became more significant.
Enhanced adsorption in the presence of Ca2+ was also found in previous studies (B. Lin et al., 2017; J. Lin et al., 2017). This phenomenon could be explained by the following aspects. First, the addition of Ca2+ could change the phosphate species in the solution into ion pairs (i.e., CaHPO40) at higher pH (Yao and Millero, 1996). Additionally, Ca2+-phosphate ion pairs could be more easily adsorbed than phosphate anions (i.e., H2PO4− and HPO42−) (B. Lin et al., 2017; J. Lin et al., 2017; Yao and Millero, 1996). Besides, the coexisting Ca2+ could be further adsorbed onto the P-loaded La-RHBC9 and form `La\\P\\Ca ternary complexes (B. Lin et al., 2017; J. Lin et al., 2017; Talebi Atouei et al., 2016). The adsorption of Ca2+ could reduce the electrostatic repulsion between P-loaded La-RHBC9 and phosphate anions; thereby facilitating the adsorption of phosphate onto La-RHBC9. Moreover, the formed ternary complexes could serve as extra adsorption sites for phosphate adsorption (Koilraj and Sasaki, 2017).
In contrast, the inhibitory effects of Mg2+ could be ascribed to the adsorption of Mg2+ competing with phosphate for hydroxyl groups on the surface as described in the following equations (Lin et al., 2018):
La‐OHþMg2þ ¼ La‐OMgð Þþ þHþ ð4Þ
La‐O− þMg2þ ¼ La‐OMgð Þþ ð5Þ
2La‐OHþMg2þ ¼ La‐Oð Þ2Mgþ 2Hþ ð6Þ
2La‐O− þMg2þ ¼ La‐Oð Þ2Mg ð7Þ
This would result in decreased availability of surface hydroxyl groups and further inhibit the adsorption of phosphate. At pH 4, the strong electrostatic forces between Mg2+ and the positively charged La-RHBC9 inhibited the adsorption of Mg2+, resulting in weaker inhibition on phosphate adsorption. Moreover, the La-RHBC9 wasmore effective in the acid pH range as discussed in Section 3.3. Furthermore, the presence ofMg2+may also enhance phosphate adsorption for the aforementioned reasons as coexisting Ca2+. When the negative effects of the adsorbed Mg2+ exceeded the enhancing effects of Mg2+ on phosphate adsorption, the adsorption of phosphate onto La-RHBC9 was finally inhibited in the presence of Mg2+.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this study, a series of RHBCs with various mesoporous rates were fabricated and La(OH)3 NPs were immobilized to the RHBCs for enhanced phosphate sequestration. The host pore structure was found to have significant effects on the adsorption properties of the immobilized La(OH)3 NPs. Generally, the La-modified RHBCs with higher host mesoporous rate exhibited higher La loading, relatively faster adsorption, higher adsorption capacity and superior stability. The resultant Lamodified RHBCs showed high pHpzc and was able to effectively remove phosphate over awide pH range of 3–10. Themesoporous structure and high pHpzc of RHBCs together enhanced the accessibility of La(OH)3 NPs to coordinate with phosphate, and the La utilization efficiency of Lamodified RHBCs was much higher than that of many other Laincorporated adsorbents.
Overall, RHBCs showed preferable properties for La immobilization and the La-RHBCs could serve as superior adsorbents for phosphate adsorption.

metadata.abstractText: • Rice husk biochars can serve as preferable host material for La(OH)3 nanoparticles. • La-modified rice husk biochars exhibited superior La utilization efficiency. • Phosphate can be captured over a wide pH rang of 3–10 with negligible La leaching. • Coexisting Ca inhibited the phosphate adsorption, while Mg enhanced the process. ⁎ Corresponding author.
